_1:
Description 1:
A 45-year-old male patient presented with a three-month history of persistent, non-radiating epigastric pain that is described as a dull ache with intermittent severity, rated at 5/10 on the pain scale. The pain is not alleviated by food intake or positional changes. The patient has a history of regular non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) use for chronic knee pain. Upon further inquiry, he reported experiencing occasional nausea and bloating. His medical history is significant for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which has been managed with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) for the past two years.
_2:
Description 2:
A 30-year-old female patient presented with a four-month history of recurrent, crampy abdominal pain in the lower left quadrant, with an average pain score of 6/10. The pain is associated with changes in bowel habits, including increased frequency of loose, non-bloody stools, as well as a feeling of incomplete evacuation. The patient reported noticing mucus in her stool on several occasions. She has no significant past medical history, and her family history is negative for gastrointestinal disorders. The symptoms appear to be exacerbated during periods of increased stress.
_3:
Description 3:
A 55-year-old male patient, who is a heavy smoker with a 30-pack-year history, presented with a persistent cough that has been ongoing for eight weeks. The cough is productive, yielding purulent sputum, and is associated with intermittent hemoptysis, which the patient estimates to be around 20–30 ml of blood per day. He reports a dull, aching chest pain behind the sternum, with an intensity of 4/10, exacerbated by deep inhalation and coughing. The patient has experienced unintentional weight loss of 10 lbs over the past two months. His medical history is notable for untreated hypertension. Family history is unremarkable for respiratory conditions.
